• Part 1 of the Binary Series: Mastering Binary Addition

  • 2025 May 31
  • Back to HQ

What if I told you 00100110 + 01010111 = 01111101 — and it’s not magic, it’s just binary. Here you learn what binary is and how binary addition actually works.

What is binary?

Binary is a base-2 number system. Each digit (called a bit) holds a value of 1 or 0, think of it like an ON/OFF switch in an electrical device.

  • 1 = ON
  • 0 = OFF

It’s the language used by computer components and almost all modern electronic devices.

Why it matters

Take a 1GiB (gibibyte) of memory, like in your computer’s RAM for example.
That equals:

  • 230 bytes = 1,073,741,824 bytes
  • Since each byte is 8 bits, that’s:
    230 × 8 = 233 bits = 8,589,934,592 bits

We want to make optimal use of this space so the computer is created in a way to constantly do binary calculations, adding, subtracting, and what you can think of is done by the components of a computer.

So it can figure out where it should point to in memory, and what data should show up, once asked for. Numbers, letters, emojis, images, and even the words you’re reading right now are all stored in binary.

Let’s look at the truth table displayed below containing five components to get to the end sum of 2 bytes added up together. It shows all input combinations and their resulting byte, which you can read downwards in the sum column.

Each row represents one bit, starting from the least significant (right) to the most significant (left). The remaining byte is built by repeating this process 8 times.

The 5 components

  • A = byte_1, starting at the top of the column at the least significant bit.
  • B = byte_2, which also starts at the top of the column at the least significant bit.
  • Carry_in the overflow from the previous bit's addition, calculated as carry out divided by 2.
  • Sum = (A + B + Carry_in) % 2, and will represent from bit_0 to bit_7 the full byte displayed starting from the rightmost at (bit_0) (least significant) and moving left (bit_7).
  • Carry_out = (A + B + Carry in) / 2, this calculation is done so we know if we need to create a carry_in for the next bit addition.

NOTE: Because computers start at index 0 by default, we do so bit_0 in base-10 would represent the number 1 so in total we have 8 positions.



The truth table explained

Carry_in is the overflow of the previous calculation. Once we have a carry_in we know that the previous Carry_out calculation was 1 bit overflow, remember:
Carry_out is the total A + B + Carry_in / 2.

NOTE: Overflow is the given location in RAM running out of space.

The Sum, as you’ve read above, sums the whole to the remainder of two, it’s used so we know what to write down when the full truth table is completed. Which leaves us with the full byte.

In this case, 01111101 equals 125 in decimal numbers.

The maximum number of bits that can be held in a byte is 8 as you probably already guessed, and if each value holds the number 1 then we have a total of 8 ones => 11111111, leaving us with the number 255. Because each one calculated to the power of two is; 128, 64, 32, 16, 8, 4, 2, 1. And all positions add up together is 255.
